title: Historic (classic) vehicles: MOT and vehicle tax

body.content:
The date your vehicle was built or first registered affects whether you need to:

- [get an MOT](/getting-an-mot)
- [pay vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax)

##Date the vehicle was built or first registered

###8 January 1977 onwards 

You must get an MOT and pay vehicle tax.

###1 January 1960 to 7 January 1977  

You must get an MOT, but don’t have to pay vehicle tax.

### Before 1 January 1960

You don't need to get an MOT or pay vehicle tax.

## What you have to do

You need to [apply for a vehicle tax exemption](/historic-vehicles/apply-for-vehicle-tax-exemption) to stop paying vehicle tax.

^ This is sometimes called putting a vehicle into the 'historic tax class'. ^

You don't need to apply to stop getting an MOT for your vehicle each year. However, you must still keep it in a roadworthy condition. 

% You can be fined up to £2,500 and get 3 penalty points for using a vehicle in a dangerous condition. %

The date your vehicle was built or first registered affects whether you need to:

  • get an MOT
  • pay vehicle tax

Date the vehicle was built or first registered

8 January 1977 onwards 

You must get an MOT and pay vehicle tax.

1 January 1960 to 7 January 1977  

You must get an MOT, but don’t have to pay vehicle tax.

Before 1 January 1960

You don’t need to get an MOT or pay vehicle tax.

What you have to do

You need to apply for a vehicle tax exemption to stop paying vehicle tax.

This is sometimes called putting a vehicle into the ‘historic tax class’.

You don’t need to apply to stop getting an MOT for your vehicle each year. However, you must still keep it in a roadworthy condition.

You can be fined up to £2,500 and get 3 penalty points for using a vehicle in a dangerous condition.

You can apply to stop paying vehicle tax from 1 April 2017 if your vehicle was built or first registered before 8 January 1977.

^ You must still tax your vehicle, but you won't need to pay. ^

## Eligible vehicles

You can apply for these vehicles to be made exempt:

- cars
- vans
- motorcycles
tricycles

### Large vehicles and buses

You can apply for these vehicles to be made exempt:

- private heavy goods vehicles (HGVs) - they can't be designed or adapted for transporting goods, or be used for driver training
- buses used for voluntary or community purposes

### Specialist vehicles

You can also apply for these vehicles to be made exempt:

- mobile cranes and pumps
- road rollers, works trucks and digging machines
- agricultural machines and mowing machines
- snowploughs and gritting vehicles
- electric vehicles
- steam vehicles


*[HGVs]: heavy goods vehicles

You can apply to stop paying vehicle tax from 1 April 2017 if your vehicle was built or first registered before 8 January 1977.

You must still tax your vehicle, but you won’t need to pay.

Eligible vehicles

You can apply for these vehicles to be made exempt:

  • cars
  • vans
  • motorcycles tricycles

Large vehicles and buses

You can apply for these vehicles to be made exempt:

  • private heavy goods vehicles (HGVs) - they can’t be designed or adapted for transporting goods, or be used for driver training
  • buses used for voluntary or community purposes

Specialist vehicles

You can also apply for these vehicles to be made exempt:

  • mobile cranes and pumps
  • road rollers, works trucks and digging machines
  • agricultural machines and mowing machines
  • snowploughs and gritting vehicles
  • electric vehicles
  • steam vehicles

parts.title: Apply for a vehicle tax exemption

body.content:
Apply at a [Post Office](http://www.postoffice.co.uk/branch-finder) that deals with vehicle tax. 

You need to take:

- the log book (V5C) in your name
- your vehicle tax reminder letter (V11), if you have one
- an MOT certificate that's valid when the tax starts, or evidence if your vehicle’s exempt from an MOT ([V112](/government/publications/declaration-of-exemption-from-mot))
- an insurance certificate or cover note (only in Northern Ireland)

^ If you don’t have the log book, download and fill in an [application for a log book (V62)](/government/publications/application-for-a-vehicle-registration-certificate). Take it to the Post Office with the £25 fee. ^

## What happens next

s1. The Post Office sends your log book to DVLA.
s2. You'll get a confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.
s3. DVLA will send you an updated log book.
s4. You'll get a refund within 6 weeks (if you're due one). [Contact DVLA](/contact-the-dvla/y/vehicle-tax-and-sorn) if it hasn't arrived after 6 weeks.


You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed.



*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[HGVs]: heavy goods vehicles

Apply at a Post Office that deals with vehicle tax.

You need to take:

  • the log book (V5C) in your name
  • your vehicle tax reminder letter (V11), if you have one
  • an MOT certificate that’s valid when the tax starts, or evidence if your vehicle’s exempt from an MOT (V112)
  • an insurance certificate or cover note (only in Northern Ireland)

If you don’t have the log book, download and fill in an application for a log book (V62). Take it to the Post Office with the £25 fee.

What happens next

  1. The Post Office sends your log book to DVLA.

  2. You’ll get a confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.

  3. DVLA will send you an updated log book.

  4. You’ll get a refund within 6 weeks (if you’re due one). Contact DVLA if it hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.

You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed.

DVLA will send you a vehicle tax reminder letter before your tax is due to expire. You'll need to [tax your vehicle](/vehicle-tax), but won't need to pay. 

% It’s illegal to drive your vehicle if you haven't taxed it. You can be fined £80 if you don't tax your vehicle on time.  %

DVLA will send you a vehicle tax reminder letter before your tax is due to expire. You’ll need to tax your vehicle, but won’t need to pay.

It’s illegal to drive your vehicle if you haven’t taxed it. You can be fined £80 if you don’t tax your vehicle on time.
